title: 114_hr4639
content: The Act is titled the "Thoroughly Investigating Retaliation Against Whistleblowers Act." It reauthorizes the Office of Special Counsel with increased funding for fiscal years 2016 to 2020. Section 1212(b) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to authorize the Special Counsel to have access to agency records and require employees to provide information during investigations. The Office must maintain the confidentiality level applied by the agency to the information provided. The Attorney General or an Inspector General may withhold access to records if disclosure could interfere with a criminal investigation or prosecution, with a written report required for the withholding. SEC. 4. WHISTLEBLOWER PROVISIONS. Section 1213 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to extend the timeframe for certain actions and require a detailed explanation for any failure to take action on disclosed information. Section 1213 of title 5, United States Code is amended to require agencies to submit a supplemental report to the Special Counsel within 180 days of proposing agency actions in response to investigations. If no action is taken, agencies must provide a reason for the inaction. SEC. 5. TERMINATION OF CERTAIN OSC INVESTIGATIONS. Section 1214(a) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to allow the Special Counsel to terminate an investigation within 30 days if the same allegation has been previously investigated, if the Office of Special Counsel lacks jurisdiction, or if the person was aware of the alleged issue. The Special Counsel can terminate an investigation within 30 days if the person knew of the alleged issue earlier than 3 years before the allegation was received. Amendments to Section 1214 of title 5, United States Code, specify the conditions under which investigations can be terminated. Amendments to Section 1214 of title 5, United States Code, specify the conditions under which investigations can be terminated, including reporting requirements. The Special Counsel is required to submit an annual report to Congress detailing the number and types of allegations of prohibited personnel practices, investigations conducted, disciplinary actions negotiated with agencies, and cases where determinations were not made within the specified time frame. The Special Counsel's annual report to Congress includes details on recommendations and reports made to other agencies, actions taken as a result, actions initiated before the Merit Systems Protection Board, stays obtained from the Board, and prohibited personnel practice complaints outcomes. The Special Counsel's annual report to Congress includes recommendations for legislation or other action, categorized by actions and outcomes in whistleblower reprisal cases and other cases. Additionally, the report includes a list of noncriminal matters referred to agency heads with related reports. The Special Counsel's annual report to Congress includes recommendations for legislation or other action in whistleblower reprisal cases and other cases, along with comments from complainants and the Special Counsel's own recommendations. Establishment of Survey Pilot Program by the Office of Special Counsel for fiscal years 2017 and 2018 to gather feedback from individuals who filed complaints or disclosures, aiming to improve customer service. Results will be included in the annual report. Suspension of other surveys during this period. Penalties under the Hatch Act. Penalties under the Hatch Act include disciplinary actions such as removal, reduction in grade, debarment, suspension, or reprimand, a civil penalty of up to $1,000, or a combination of these penalties for violations of specific sections. The amendment applies to violations occurring after the enactment of the Act. The Special Counsel must create regulations within 2 years of the Act's enactment to carry out their functions, including sections 1213, 1214, and 1215 of the United States Code. The regulations will be published in the Federal Register.
